name: Hit-Bit 20
keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard, 70 keys (including 5 F-keys and 4 arrow keys)
coprocessor: Texas Instruments TMS 9918/A  or TMS 9928/A (Japan : 60 Hz) or TMS 9929/A (Europe : 50 Hz)
graphics: Mode 2 : 256 x 192 with 16 colors (Hires mode)Mode 3 : 64 x 48 with 16 colors (Multi colour mode)32 sprites
sound: General Instruments AY-3-8910 Programmable Sound Generator3 channels, 8 octaves
ports: 2 x controller connectors, 2 cardridge slots, Tape-recorder interface (1200/2400 bauds), RGB video output, Centronics interface
description:
The Hit-Bit 20 is a very basic MSX "1" computer. It looks very similar to the Hit-Bit 10. If someone could tell us the difference that would be nice.

It seems to have been sold only in Spain... The Hit-Bit 20P model has a spanish keyboard, which is strange, as if we follow the Sony naming logic, the Spanish model would have been called Hit-Bit 20S, and not Hit-Bit 20P which was reserved for PAL models which didn't need a special keyboard.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the "tilde" key, next to the "L" key. This is a spanish keyboard.</blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>1983 Hannover show advert. <br><br> Advert said that 30,000 Kaypro II systems were already sold in the U.S.A.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMTEXT BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The brochure says:<br><font color="#666666"> When you buy, lease or rent word processing equipment from AM Jacquard Systems, you get our total commitment, now and in the future, that assures the successful installation and operation of your AMtext word processing system. <br><br> To support that commitment, we have offices in over 100 cities throughout North America staffed with skilled professionals ready to meet your neads with planning, training. supplies, and service... <br><br> ...The AMtext 100 is a true shared resource, multifunction information system capable of supporting multiple work stations and peripherals simultaneously. <br><br> The Amtext 425 and 425A are powerful stand-alone work stations with a full-page video display <br><br> The AMtext 225 is a low-cost system that turns electric typewriters into flexible text editors. <br><br> The AMtext product line includes a complete selection of peripheral devices, including telecommunications, an optical character reader. magnetic card reader, phototypesetters, daisy wheel printers. high-speed line and matrix printers, as well as mass storage on floppy and hard disk drive units.  <br><br></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUSTAR AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Compustar standard features in 1983:<br> - 350 KB / 750 KB / 1.5 MB workstation disk capacities<br> - 10 to 144 MB storage options<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Compustar is built and backed by the company that's been in the microcomputer business as long as microcomputers have been in business. Would you trust your business to anything less?</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (NOV. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the only SILEX advert known so far... <br><br> It says : "Silex, a stone in our competitors garden." <br><br> Silex means flint in french, a stone mainly used in prehistoric times as tools and weapons. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>DEC Advertises its range of networking products.<p class="petitgris">Byte magazine</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Japanese selling price was of 58.000 yen.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"TO8D, the smart present"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Yoann Riou for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 36 MHZ. IN 1982?</strong></font><br><blockquote>The title of this advert was very optimistic. In fact, the 36 Mhz speed is obtained by adding the speed of the 9 x Z80 cards installed into the system. The maximum system speed was in fact 4 Mhz.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>In the same magazine, Robert Hardling, the marketing manager of Atari Corporation said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> I envisage the situation where each house in 20 years time will have two, three or maybe more computers, ranging from a basic game machine through a home computer for education and home management and culminating in a fully fledged hyghly sophisticated computing work-station.<br> In the future, there may be only 3-4 major worldwide manufacturers. The IBM's, Apple's, Commodore's and Atari's of the world.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CREATIVITY BUILT-IN</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a French advert from december 1985 for a special christmas pack : TO-7/70 + Microsoft Basic level 5 + tape recorder + Colorpaint + Basic initiation cube for "only" 3990 FF. <br><br> "All the world in a present"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOL PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><u>Sol Systems price list (january 1977)</u></b> <br><br> (K) = Kit   (A) = Assembled<br><br> <b>Sol Terminal Computers<br> </b>SOL-PC Single board (K) <b> $475</b><br> SOL-10 (K) <b> $795</b><br> SOL-20 (K) <b> $995</b> <br><br> <b>Memory Modules</b> <br> PROM Resident Assembly Language (A) <b>$425</b><br> Interpretive Simulator (PROM option) (A) <b>$95</b><br> Text Editing (PROM option) (A) <b>$95</b><br> Erasable PROM module (K) <b>$65  </b>(A) <b>$89</b> <br> 4 Kb. low power static Ram (K) <b> $159</b>  (A) <b> $195</b><br> 8 Kb. low power static Ram (K) <b>$295</b>  (A) <b>$375</b><br> 16 Kb. Dynamic Ram  (A) <b>$529</b> <br><br> <b>Interface Modules</b><br> Parallel / Serial I/O Module  (K) <b>$149</b>  (A) <b>$199</b><br> System cassette interface  (K) <b>$87 </b> (A) <b>$119</b><br> Video Display Module  (K) <b>$199 </b> (A) <b>$295</b><br> <br> <b>Mass Storage System</b><br> Helios II Disk system  (K) <b>$1895</b>  (A) <b>$2295</b><br><br> <b>Software<br> </b>(C) = Cassette  (P) = Paper tape<br> Basic 5  (P) <b>$19.95</b><br> 8K Basic (C) <b>$29</b>  (P) <b>$37</b><br> New 8080 Focal  (C) <b>$14.50</b>  <br> Trek 80 Video game  (C) <b>$9.50</b>  (P) <b>$14.50</b><br> GamePack 1  (C) <b>$9.50</b>  (P) <b>$14.50</b><br> MathPack Video calculator  (C) <b>$14.50</b>  (P) <b>$19.50</b><br> Assembler  (C) <b>$14.50</b>  (P) <b>$19.50</b><br> ALS 8  (C) <b>$35</b> (P) <b>$45</b> </blockquote>

MEGA RAM DISK 256|||from DDX (Brazil)|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEGA RAM DISK 256</strong></font><br><strong>> from DDX (Brazil)</strong><br><blockquote>This is the famous Megaram cartridge made in Brzail, used to play all Konami cracked Megarom games.6401999243</blockquote>

Panasonic  FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W|||Scanner/Printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PANASONIC  FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W</strong></font><br><strong>> Scanner/Printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>The FS-IFA1 is the printer/scanner interface (left on the picture) and the FW-RSU1W is the handheld scanner (right on the picture). These expansions are for MSX2 systems.</blockquote>
Sony HBI-232|||RS232c cartridge|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SONY HBI-232</strong></font><br><strong>> RS232c cartridge</strong><br><blockquote>Used to connect serial printers.</blockquote>

Yamaha mouse #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This mouse was compatible with all MSX systems. It connects to the first Joystick port.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>
Yamaha mouse #2||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Brand new!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>

Philips VW0020|||80-col dot-matrix printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS VW0020</strong></font><br><strong>> 80-col dot-matrix printer</strong><br><blockquote>This printer was a rebadged version of the Seikosha GP-500.<br>  It was a 80-column, 50 CPS model with a 7x5 dot matrix head.<br>  Commodore and Atari used same hardware basis for their MPS-801 and 1029 printers. </blockquote>

Sanyo DR-202||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANYO DR-202</strong></font><br><blockquote>The ADSS system allowed to quickly search a specific program in a cassette tape and load it. Seach time for a C60 cassette was less than 1 minute.</blockquote>

Bit-corder||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> BIT-CORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cassete recorder dedicated to Hit-Bit MSX systems, though it could be used with any home computers.</blockquote>

emulator.name: fMSX official Homepage
emulator.description: fMSX is a portable MSX emulator ported on : Amiga OS, Mac OS, MS DOS, OS/2, Sony Playstation, Risc OS, Towns OS, Unix / X, Win95 / NT, X68K.

emulator.name: openMSX - The MSX emulator that aims for perfection.
emulator.description: This new MSX emulator can reproduce, among many other MSX, MSX2and  MSX2+ machines, both Panasonic Turbo-R models. Be sure to get the catapult frontend and the system roms from FUNET.
